item.description:
2- 4 Players compete to build and mine slate in North Wales.

Players roll three dice to determine what actions they can take, though money can be spent to alter the die roll. Actions available to players include building a mine, selling slate or take a development action. The development actions either benefit players in the final scoring or allow players to add to their stock, adjust a die or improve the return from the sell slate action.

At the end of the game players score points for developments, mines owned and money


'Slate' is second game in Martin Wallace's series of four designed for the 2011 issues of Spielbox (included in Edition 93. The game requires the materials provided in issue 3 of Spielbox 2011.

The first game in the Series is 'Great Western'

The game was one of the titles in the final round of the "Hippodice Spieleautorenwettbewerb 2010".

The players try to get the most profitable contracts in this competition. But which player is playing for which guild? This secret is only revealed at the end of the game!

During each turn, the player rolls a d6 and places a matching numbered tile on a six-sided guild space. The game ends, when all 24 numbered tiles are placed on the game board. Depending on the chosen spaces and the value of the numbered tiles, different guilds will score victory points.

Voyage en France is the same game as Journey through Europe, Deutschlandreise or Weltreise.

Each player receives some destination cards with places in France. The players have to move along the board by throwing a die. The first player who has visited all of his/her destination cards and arrives back in the starting place wins the game.

Merchandising game

Players have to roll dice, move meeples over the board and reach target spots in order to get Bargain cards.

This is a simple roll and move game. Up to four players try to get their three pieces all the way around the board, avoiding the monster on the way.

The monster travels a track around the middle of the board. He doesn't move until the first six is rolled, after which he will move every time the dice is rolled BEFORE the player who rolled the dice moves the same number of spaces.

Players can choose to travel the shorter dangerous path, or take safer longer routes, so there is a small amount of risk management involved.

The game makes use of a "popper" built into the centre of the board that is depressed to roll the dice.

From the back of the box:

A fun and tense family game for 2 to 4 players. Can you get round the board without getting eaten by the monster? One false move and the monster's gonna get yer!

CONTENTS:
Playing board with centre dice-popper.
12 playing pieces (three each in four colours).
Monster.
Instructions leaflet.

A simple word game in which you make words of four letters or more using 112 letter cards.

Cards are drawn from a deck, until someone can make a word. The player sets that word aside and it will count towards his or her final score. Play then continues in the same manner, but if someone can create a new word by adding newly drawn letter cards to a word someone else has already made, then that word is stolen. More complicated words are harder to make but are more difficult to steal.

The first player to make a prearranged number of words (either by making them with "free" letters from the card deck or by adding to words already in play, thereby stealing them), is the winner.

From the box:

Deriving from one of the oldest word construction games, Early Words is the fastest, the most skilful and the most cunning.

If you like games where a player suddenly sticks his tongue out to another player, where another player answers by flapping like a bird and where the players growl, squeak and grunt; where they moo, break wind(oops!) and pull their noses, then you'll love Crazy Harry, an outrageous card game with simple rules.

gameplay:
One by one each player puts a card down on a stack in the middle with 2 drawings one them. The player who puts the card down chooses which drawing he impersonates and the other player must do the other one. If a player misses or is to soon, he must take the complete stack. their are a few exceptions like the fish (only the fish gets impersonated) and crazy harry (everybody must lay his hand on the stack, the player whose hand is on top, must take the stack). The player with no cards left, wins

with: 55 playing cards

Taken from the rules of the PC game of the same name, Risk II is played much like classic Risk. The goal is still world domination, battle resolutions are based on the luck of dice, and the theme remains vaguely Napoleonic. However, there are significant and interesting differences. Most important is the use of simultaneous planning and execution of attacks. Players write down their plans, and once revealed, battles are resolved in a prescribed fashion. Also of note is the addition of several territories and connection points, changing the values of continents and making them more difficult to hold; yes, gone are the days of establishing an easy bastion in Australia. The dice rules are significantly different, using 12-sided dice of various strength. And still, there are other alterations that change the nature of the game, yet it retains the flavor of Risk. Simply put, you are still playing Risk, but you no longer have to wait an hour between turns before you can play again; now it is always your turn.

Normandy, June 6th, 1944 – as you land on the well-defended beaches, a German machine gun nest is killing your comrades like flies. You must do something!

In D-Day Dice, players are Allied soldiers trying to organize improvised units for an attack against the machine gun nest. Each player starts the game with a unit of a few soldiers and nothing else. As the game progresses, they will collect resources and advance on the beach, sector by sector, as their unit grows stronger and deadlier. They will succeed...or die trying.

D-Day Dice is a multiplayer co-op game, where all players play their turn simultaneously and must help each other in order to stay alive. It also includes solitaire optional rules. Although built around dice rolling, this game is about resource management (soldiers, specialists, items and courage) and knowing when to move your unit. Resources are kept from turn to turn, so the players can plan ahead.

Note: This listing is for the commercial version of D-Day Dice. To download and play the game now, go to D-Day Dice: Free Trial Version.

Expanded by 3 marketed expansions:

D-Day Dice: Operation Neptune 
D-Day Dice: Atlantikwall
D-Day Dice: Normandy

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Get ready to fight the war anew! The Dust Tactics: Revised Core Set is the perfect introduction for new players or a great expansion for veterans. It includes all new, never-before-released miniatures exclusive to this Core Set, an updated and comprehensive rulebook, the "Victory Bridge" scenario book, six custom dice, two double-sided terrain posters (each the size of six terrain tiles), ten unit cards, nine double-sided hazard squares, two ammo-crates, and two anti-tank traps.

The Allies are ready to lay waste to their Axis foes with their new forces. Meanwhile, the Blutkreuz Korps refuse to be bested on any field of battle. Their new Axis troops are equally powerful. With astonishing abilities and firepower, it will be a struggle deciding which side you want to fight for.

The included terrain posters unique to the Revised Core Set introduce Dust Tactics players to new terrain elements featured in the "Victory Bridge" scenario book. These terrain posters are a new warfare experience due to the new environment they offer players: a bridge and building structures, as well as new terrain symbols. The "Victory Bridge" scenario book offers players six never-before-seen scenarios with which they can carry out a campaign. England's Cobden Bridge has suddenly become the strategic location for gaining access to Southampton. Can your faction take control of the bridge, and gain the advantage of advancing into southern England?

item.description:
The whole carddeck are distributed among the players.
The players play the top card of their hand in the center of the table face-up. Whenever the "Butterfly stop" card is played the one who played it must exclaims "Butterfly stop" and is entitled to all the cards that have been played, but in case he omits to do so before the next card has been played, the cards must remain on the table. 
At the end of the game the player holding the greatest number of cards scores 5 points.The one holding the card "Regal Silver Wing" scores 3 points and all the other butterfly cards scores 1 point each. Player with the most points is the winner.

In this game teams compete to collect one card from each of three categories (Object, Action, and Creature).

Each member of a team brings 5 items (together the items must all fit in the palms of the hands of the person who brought the items) and those items are then used as props for that team.

On a turn a member of a team rolls the die, draws a card, and then using the props for the team (those items which each member of the team brought) attempts to get the other players of the team to guess the word on the card that corresponds to the roll of the die.

If a team fails to guess the word, the other team(s) have an opportunity to guess the word and steal the card from the team.

The first team to collect an Object card, an Action card, and a Creature card wins the game.

An abstract two-player strategy game, CENTRE (formally SPOOLS) has only a few basic rules of play that combine neatly with the unique design of the board to produce a new and different game.

By positioning and relocating pieces, players attempt to maneuver their own Emperor to the center circle of the board -- aided by their four Defenders and four Marauders, each of which possesses specific movement and attack capabilities.

Another unique aspect of the game is the one-way interaction between pieces: Defenders may attack only Marauders, Marauders may attack only Emperors, and Emperors may attack only Defenders and Marauders.

Steeped in Japanese folklore, SUTAKKU was originally developed to teach the common man the foibles of wishing for more than he had.

In this quick-playing, push-your-luck dice game, you attempt to create the tallest stack of dice in order to gain the highest score per turn. To play, roll three dice and add two of them to an ever-climbing stack of dice. You can choose to stop rolling and score your stacked dice at any time, but pushing your luck will net you more points if you succeed. Continue as long as you dare – but like the stonecutter of legend, who was never satisfied, you may find yourself with naught, right back where you began. The wise will distinguish ambition from reaching beyond one's means.
 SUTAKKU is beautifully crafted with classic Japanese design aesthetics and features hand-inked brush art characters on premium engraved dice. These twelve dice are ¾" on a side, perfect for stacking. The game also includes a cloth dice bag, stacking board, and scorepad.

item.description: this was a promotional game published for maredsous cheese. the purpose of the game is to find the hidden treasure in the abbey of maredsous. to find the treasure you must roll the dice, collect coins and answer questions. the game has 2 stacks of cards. 1 difficult and one easy.

A game of imagination and insight in which you make up words from the letters that chance brings your way. The multitude of variations that crop up as you play the game make every game go different and exciting.

containing:
13 letter dice (d6)
1 cup
1 timer (1 minute)

One of the players controls the game:
He or she takes charge of throwing the dice and making sure, with the aid of a sand-glass timer, that the players do not overrun the time. To begin the game he puts the timer on the table and throws the thirteen dice. each player, using the letters that turn up on the letter face of the dice, then tries to make a word. each letter has a value which is indicated beside it. The player who, within the allotted time, manages to make the word with the highest score (the sum of all letters used) is the winner.

Free translation of the back of the box

At the gate of Raveleijn the adventure begins for Joost, Thomas, Emma, Lisa and Maurits. Here starts a dangerous excursion through the woods, on the way to free the city Raveleijn. As knights you fight together against malicious Graffers. Use your special strength to become as strong as possible for the ultimate fight. 
In the final battle the powerful count Graveheart awaits you. Only the bravest knights survive this last fight. 
Who becomes the hero of Raveleijn?

This family game was made to promote the new attraction 'Raveleijn' in the Efteling amusement park.

Goal of the game: Free Ravelijn city of the mean count Graveheart and his Graffers

Each player chooses a color and the accompanying character. Each character has a special characteristic that he can use in the fights against the Graffers.
On one side of the board you will fight against the Graffers by rolling the dice. Other players can come to help you. For each "hit" you get a card. After the defeat of all the Graffers (5), the board will be turned and you will prepare for the final fight against count Graveheart.
The player who has the smallest value with the obtained cards gives up his character and will play count Graveheart. 
The obtained cards from the previous round will give you life points for this fight. The better you fought the Graffers, the stronger you are to fight count Graveheart!!
Each time you can beat the count in a fight, you will get a coin. As soon as the count looses all his life points, the player that has the majority of the coins wins the game.
Count Graveheart wins the game if he can defeat all other players.

item.description:
"The Off-Balance Game For Levelheaded People"

This is a vintage dexterity game from 1969. Based on the business executives shown on the cover illustration Trial & Balance was the kind of decorative item a corporate ladder-climber would keep on his desk.

The challenge is based on a fulcrum and balance beam with six slots spaced at regular intervals. There are six small weighted tokens that are maneuvered in these slots during play as the beam wobbles like a teeter-totter.

The object of Triple Flip game is for a player to have the least number of disks in his or her goal after all disks are in the goals. This battery-operated game has air blown through holes in the game board which allows disks to move on a cushion of air.

Contents:

 1 Battery-Operated game unit (with 3 sets of flippers)
 1 Plastic stopper bar
 3 Plastic goals
 12 Game disks

Players try to slide the puck off the bumpers into the right holes. Object is to be the first to get 4 in a row to win the game.

Contents:

 2 part electronic game base
 2 sliders
 16 yellow discs
 16 red discs
 6 super rubberbands
 8 pegs & 4 legs

Released in Spielerei No. 3

A game based on an idea from the movie "Quintett" from Robert Altmann.

Each player receives 3 playing pieces in one color. Additionally 3 dice are required.

A game is played in three rounds, each round consists of two phases: At the start of a round, a game chief is determined by rolling dice. This chief places one playing piece of each player on the hunting circle, to determine the hunting order: The order shows, which color can be attacked or must defend itself from the other colors.

Afterwards the players place their remaining playing pieces on the game board. Depending on the dice numbers they move their pieces and try to attack the appropriate colors. Certain dice combinations are keeping the own playing pieces safe. The game chief can redistribute the hunting order during the round. The winner of this phase plays against the game chief in a second phase. The player with remaining playing pieces on the game board wins the round.

Released in the magazine Spielerei No. 4.

Besides the game board you need three different playing pieces, four dice and paper and pen.

At the start of the game every player chooses one of the embassies at the edge of the game board and secretly chooses one of the playing pieces as a double agent.

The playing pieces start in the center of the game board and the players try to move them into their chosen embassies. All players roll their dice. Starting with the player getting highest result, the players moves one of the playing pieces. The players an voluntarily use less movement points or can cooperate with other players to move their agents as wished.

At the end of the game the players score points for agents in their embassies and for their double agents. The player with most points wins a game of "Überläufer".

Released in the magazine Spielerei No. 5.

Each player receives 6 playing pieces of the same color, representing the sheeps and a differently colored playing piece, representing a dog.

With help of their dogs the players try to chase the sheeps into their enclosure. The sheeps start the game on their starting spaces. The dogs are in their kennels.

A player's turn consists of two actions: Firstly, he moves his dog one space in any of the eight directions. Secondly, he moves all sheep standing on one of the orthogonal or diagonal lines away from his dog.

The first player with all his sheep in his enclosure wins the game.

Released in magazine Spielerei No. 8.

Both players receive 12 playing pieces and places them on his base line.

Players take turns and move a single piece when it is their turn. The playing spaces both determine the distance and the direction of the moving pieces. White - one space, yellow - two spaces, red - three spaces. Spaces with own playing pieces are ignored during the move, opposite playing pieces are removed.

Last player with playing pieces wins the game.

Place 5 at the "Hippodice Spieleautorenwettbewerb 1989".

Released in the magazine Spielerei No. 15.

You try to geet the most victory points at game end.

The playing board shows a game track, a points track and a bonus track. Players start with 3 playing pieces on the game track. By rolling a die they move the pieces on the game board. On certain spaces the playing pieces can move from the game track to the points track and further on to the bonus track. Players can remove opposing playing pieces.

Game ends as soon as the first player has no playing pieces left on the outer track. All players count the points on the spaces of their playing pieces. Highest score wins the game.

Hexteroyd is an abstract strategy game for 2 players with a background theme of Asteroid Mining. It plays in approximately 20 minutes.
Players take turn placing and removing pawns (the Colonies) on an hexagonal board (the Asteroid belt) with 5 hexagonal cells (the Asteroids) per side.
Playing the Colonies allow to have the controls of the cells through double-sided discs (the Mines).
Aim of the game is having control of the most valuable group of Mines (a Chain): the value of a Chain is given by the sum of the values of the adjacent Colonies.

The game will participate in an Abstract Strategy Game Design Contest in the mathematics festival "Tutto è Numero" in Caldè (Italy) at the end of July 2011

What's so special about Hexteroyd ?

Hexteroyd is a kind of connection game but with several twists:
 - First and foremost, you don't need to connect distant parts of the board. You must connect points to... gain points !
 - The pawns you use are shared between the players and have a double role: they allow the players to make actions and they are the points themselves: positive if you connect them on the board, negative if you keep them in your hand.
 - You don't directly place the connecting pieces on the board: they come into play as a consequence of your playing a pawn, whether you place it on, or remove it from, the board.
 - Connecting pieces (the discs) aren't fix, they have a certain degree of variability as the result of players' actions: once they are on the board, they remain on their cell, but they change owner, therefore changing the connected pawns.
 Thanks to these characteristics, some parts of the board (usually the peripheral ones) are constantly subject to subtle but meaningful changes and the victory is somewhat uncertain till the end.

The strategic aspect of Hexteroyd originates in the different ways in which you can use pawns: if you tend to empty your hand, you will have more territory control but less mobility; if you keep them in hand you risk to lose points in the end if you can't get rid of them.

The game consists of two phases, a placement phase followed by a movement phase. The two players White and Black each have twelve pieces.

PLACEMENT PHASE:
Beginning with White, the players alternate placing one of their twelve pieces on one of the 37 crossing points on the board.
Once all pieces have been placed, the movement phase begins. A piece can be captured during this phase (see below).

MOVEMENT PHASE:
The players alternate moving one of their pieces to an adjacent and empty crossing point. A piece can be captured during this phase (see below). If a player has only 4 remaining pieces, they are allowed to move their piece to any empty crossing point.

QUADRATES:
A quadrate occurs when a piece is placed such that the 4 corners of a square are occupied by that player's pieces. Quadrates come in 6 different sizes. To form a quadrate, a player must have their pieces on all 4 corners of a square composed of either 2,4,8,16,18, or 32 triangles.

The table below indicates the number of possible quadrates composed of a given number of triangles:

No. of Triangles/No. of Quadrates
2 - 24
4 - 12
8 - 13
16 - 5
18 - 4
32 - 1

For any of the larger quadrates (8,16,18,32), the quadrate is invalid if there is an opposing piece on any position along the side.Only friendly or empty positions are allowed along the edges (sides) of a quadrate.

CAPTURE:
If after placing a piece, a quadrate is formed, the player can remove an opponent piece which does not itself form a quadrate with 3 other pieces.

Once a player has only 3 remaining pieces, they lose the game. If the same position occurs 3 times, then the game is declared a draw.

Notes:
o In rare cases, all of a player's pieces may be trapped thus requiring the player to pass.
o Danish Quarto has some similiarities to the Morris family of European board games, but also shares important features of a Chinese game named `Fang`

item.description:
From the back of the box:
Are you ready for your mystery date?
The game with the electronic talking phone
The game changes every time you play!
So use the clues you hear and see if you can solve each mystery

Mystery Date: The Game With The Electronic Talking Phone

This is the 1999 version of Mystery Date but is vastly different than the others. This is more like Electronic Dream Phone!

The classic mystery game for girls is updated for the new millennium. With 3 kinds of fun mysteries to solve - Dating Line - Mystery Line - Party Planning Line.

Dating Line: Be the first player to find out which boy wants to ask you out on a date. (There is only one secret Mystery Boy chosen per game - the same for all players. It changes for each new game you begin)

Mystery Line: Be the first player to find out who the Mystery Boy is depending on one of threee randomly selected themes:

 What boy was voted class president and how many votes did he get? or
 What boy won the science contest and how much money did he win? or
 What boy is the captain of the soccer team and how many goals did he score?




Party Line: Be the first player to get six boys to come to your party.

Game play is generally calling one of the boys (from the cards in your hand) and listening to the clue he gives, look at the pictures in the frames, and then record the information on your clue sheet.

name.value: Monster in My Pocket Battle Cards

item.description:
Monster in My Pocket Battle Cards is a simple game played by two or more. The game features a deck of 48 cards, each displaying a Monster in My Pocket monster (eg. 'Werewolf', 'Hobgoblin', 'Manticore') along with five statistics: intelligence, strength, speed, weakness and point value (a total of the other categories), plus two Wild Cards.

After the deck is dealt out, each player turns over their top card. A die is rolled to determine which category is being assessed (rolling a 6 is 'you pick') and players compare cards. The player with the highest value in the chosen category wins the cards in play and puts them at the bottom of their pile. Ties are resolved by playing another round, with the eventual winner collecting all of the acumulated cards. Wild Cards win a round automatically.

After each round the die is passed along and rounds are played until one player has won all of the other cards.

The game came packaged with two Monster in My Pocket collectible figures ('The Beast' and 'Witch').

item.description:
The object is to win, and not to lose. Win, Don’t Lose is a fast, fun and hilarious card game with only a handful of rules. While there are routes to victory described in the rules, many of the cards supply their own way to win, such as setting your opponents on fire, or managing to stick around long enough to get your tax return. The game has multiple "modules", which can be added over time, so that a new player can play the basic game after only a minute of explanation. Each module adds another rule to the game, and the game builds on itself.

Win, Don't Lose is a public domain game, so anyone is free to make their own copy of the game.

item.description:
In the year of 1787, Brazil was still a colony of Portugal.

The Portuguese empire imposed high taxes (called "Derrama") upon the wealthy ones, trying to get as much gold as possible. Under pressure, influential Brazilians gather to organize a liberty movement by writing articles, poems and manifests, spreading freedom ideas taken from USA's recent act of independence and from the French Revolution.

A group of conspirators, called Inconfidentes, gathered on the state of Minas Gerais, a place that concentrated a lot of gold and valuable gems.

There are six characters on the game, five of them are Inconfidentes: the poet, the farmer, the bachelor, the soldier and the priest, each of them with a unique power. The last one is an imperial guard.

On each round, players choose and move the Inconfidentes, however more than one play may select the same character. Whenever this happens, they must blind bid to decide who will be the leader of that character.

Players vie to spread the ideas through publishing texts (tiles) and hide them around the city, Ouro Preto, formerly named as Vila Rica, and get the population's approval, supporting the struggle to make Minas Gerais free from Portugal. These conspirators also made part of Freemasonry's secret association, and they try to build the first Freemasonry's secret house to support their fight.

When they publish their own texts and get the texts from the others, players make "inconfidência" points (victory points). Furthermore, a character may become a Freemason. If a player manages to get to the 33rd. degree of Freemasonry (all five characters become Freemasons), he becomes a Master Freemason. This gives an alternative ending to the game by finishing the game earlier, and changes Brazilian history! setting Minas Gerais free from Portugal.

If no one gets to be a Master Freemason until 1789, the year of the ninth and last round, everyone goes to jail. 
The player with more points (tiles) from texts published by other players, gold retrieved and Freemasonry degrees is the "inconfidência" martyr and the winner.

Not to forget that the historic martyr, Tiradentes, became widely famous afterwords, although was unfortunately killed, hanged for treason by Portugal.

item.description:
Calciocart is a game of simulated football with special cards that reproduce all the tactical and technical situations that may occur during a football game.
 The cards are divided into three groups: Attack, Defense and Goalie.
 The game is played between two players. Each choose 12 attack cards and 12 defense, which wants to use among the more than 100 that make up their decks, depending on choice of tactics.
 The first player plays a card of attack (usually a passing) if the defender has a defense card that cancels that played by the opponent, he becomes the attacker, otherwise the first player may shoot at goal.
 If an attempt on goal is saved the game will restart with the roles attacker / defender reversed, otherwise the attacking player has scored a goal.
 After playing for 45 minutes, the first time end and pass on second.
 After 90 minutes of play the player who has scored the most number of goals wins.

The Fortune Building Securities Game.

Starting with $10,000 players buy stock in leading corporations- selling them back for profit or loss depending on whether they're in a Recession, Depression, Prosperity or Recovery.

First player to reach $50,000 in cash and stocks is the winner.

Stumps is a new and exciting 20-20 cricket card and dice game.

Pick your team, choose your favourite players, friends or even family. Win the toss and decide whether to bat or bowl.

Bat and decide on when to attack and when to defend. Be aware attacking can lead to losing wickets but play too defensively and your score might not be good enough.

Read the bowler's tactics and anticipate the next delivery.

Bowl tactically to restrict runs and take wickets. Bowl a good length or bowl short, and decide wisely when to use wicket taking deliveries such as Yorkers or Slower balls.

Play one-versus-one or in a group to create the ultimate team.

[Description taken from rear of game box]

name.value: Sergeants Miniatures Game: Day of Days

item.description: This game combines elements of boardgames and miniatures, in a system that is card-driven. Cards drive the impulses that take place during each turn, and each player has a deck of cards, made up from the troops under his or her command. Each soldier's "deck" of cards reflects abilities and traits-- perhaps about how well they shoot or how slowly they move or how attracted they are to things like fresh milk, hot food, or loot. There are some Soldiers (called "Characters") included in the base game (Day of Days) which are common, but the others in DoD and all that are purchased separately have unique characteristics (which all balance out to be "equal" according to a complex math formula which is seamless to the players). So players can only get the best out of their forces after they have learned each soldier's strengths and weaknesses. "Day of Days" includes moveable mapboard tiles, hand-painted 20mm miniatures (by FAA), scenarios, cards (several decks!) and everything needed to play. Additional Soldiers give more choices and more fun.

link.value: Greater Than Games (Dice Hate Me Games)

item.description:
This game attempts to capture the feel of a Horror Movie in a Board Game. Players start off as survivors of an airplane crash, they know that something is wrong but not what. They must first leave the safety of the abandoned village and collect clues from other island locations. Once they have collected enough clues a Horror themed Goal is revealed that usually requires gathering certain objects and bringing them to a given location (eg. To escape from the island you must take the motor from the docks and repair it in the workshop, and return with the keys and gasoline to escape).

As the players move about the island they will come under attack from the Peril Deck. The hand of cards each player holds represents the energy they have to escape from the attacks, attacks chip away at your hand (the Action Deck also represents how much daylight is left). If you ever run out of cards in your hand after an attack you die... but the player can always return to the village to grab another survivor to wander off to find out what is going on.

The game contains a few horror themed cards including "I know what to do", "it's now or never", and my favorite for twist endings "It's not what you think" all balanced to bring a horror movie to your tabletop in about half-an-hour.

NOTE: All files necessary to play the game are located in the files section below :-)

item.description:
From the publisher:

You are a young captain in charge of your own fleet of ships, seeking fame and fortune. Conquer the islands and increase your wealth so you can be a powerful admiral.

Have you found a section of ocean where there are several islands that are not under the power of any kingdom or country and it is your duty to land on them and claim its riches for you. Be careful as other pirates have been established on nearby islands and are in search of new domains, you will fight them, showing who is the most powerful captain, using your ships to take out your opponents.

Have fun, managing your ships, conquering islands landing in their ports, increase your wealth, and if necessary destroy your opponents by blowing up your traps. Who will be the most successful captain?

The board represents a section of ocean with several islands, each with its port and wealth. Each island has a number that represents wealth and every time you take possession of an island, its richness is added to the total wealth of the player.

Each turn each player can make up to six actions that can be: Build, move or disembark. Additionally, the player may attack one or more opponents or blow up one of his traps.

There are two ways to end the game:

1 - Time limit: At the beginning of the game a limit of time is proposed. Upon completion of the time the winner is determined by the number of ships that the player have on the board and the wealth earned.

2 - Total Victory: The game ends when one player remains on the board or when a player takes possession of all shipyards.


Del editor:

Conviertete en un poderoso capitán acumulando riquezas y dominios.

Eres un joven capitán a cargo de tu propia flota de barcos, buscando fama y fortuna. Debes conquistar la mayor cantidad de islas, aumentando tu riqueza para que seas un poderoso almirante.

Has encontrado un sector del océano donde se encuentran varias islas que no están bajo el poder de ningún reinado o país y es tu deber desembarcar en ellas y reclamar sus riquezas para ti. Ten cuidado, ya que otros corsarios se han establecido en islas cercanas y se encuentran en la búsqueda de nuevos dominios; deberás enfrentarte a ellos, demostrando quien es el mas poderoso capitán, utilizando tus barcos para eliminar a tus oponentes.

Diviértete, manejando tus naves; conquista islas desembarcando en sus puertos, aumenta tus riquezas, enfrenta a tus oponentes y si es necesario destruyelos haciendo explotar tus trampas. ¿Quién será el capitán mas exitoso?

El tablero representa un sector del océano con varias islas, cada una con su puerto y riquezas. Cada isla tiene un número que representa su riqueza y cada vez que se toma posesión de una isla, su riqueza se suma al total de las riquezas del jugador.

En cada turno cada jugador puede realizar hasta seis acciones que pueden ser: Construir, mover o desembarcar. Adicionalmente el jugador puede atacar a uno ó mas oponentes o hacer explotar una de sus trampas.

Hay dos formas de terminar el juego:

1- Límite de tiempo: Al comienzo del juego se propone un límite de tiempo determinado. Al terminarse el tiempo establecido de juego se decide el ganador según los barcos que se tengan en el tablero y la riqueza ganada.

2- Victoria Total: El juego termina, cuando queda un solo jugador en el tablero o cuando un jugador se apodera de todos los astilleros.

name.value: Wer weiss mehr und traut sich auch?

item.description:
Wer weiss mehr und traut sich auch? ("Who knows more and will dare too much?") is a party game for 2-5 teams (2-15 players) that will test their powers of concentration and cultural knowledge. In each round, the teams first bid on how many items they can name from a particular category – flowers, car brands, fish, alcoholic drinks – then the team with the high bid sees whether they can live up to their claim. If they fail to do so, the other teams could score points instead. The team that collects the most points wins.

The Box Contain:

1 Board
5 Pawns in different colors
6 Gray token used to mark the category choosed during the game
1 Black token used to mark the number of terms declared
110 Category cards: total of 660 categories!
1 Mechanical timer

The Game will be presented at Essen Spiel 2011 - Booth 5-34 at the W&L SpielSpass stand.

In 80 Tagen durch Ozeanien is a card game of the Game of Authors and Top Trumps school. It is noteworthy primarily for incorporating mechanisms to allow the games to be playable with incomplete sets, thus allowing for a collectible format.

The photographs of marine fauna are rather nice. The card ratings, on the other hand, occasionally seem somewhat dubious.

Erudition™ jump-starts the road to reading. The game takes players on a fun adventure through literacy land, complete with common land marks and street signs. You will enjoy an ice cream cone, encounter a construction site, ride a train and play on a playground. Recognize a sight word and you earn a bonus roll. Be the first player to reach the library and you are a winner!

The sight word game cards represent about 50% of all English text. Game cards are categorized by reading level so children of all ages can play together. Through interaction with sight words, new readers enhance their reading skills while playing a fun game.

Game cards are categorized to promote differentiated instruction so children of all reading levels can play together! They choose from one of four game cards:

26 blue game cards – upper and lower case letters and their consonant and short vowel sounds
94 green game cards – beginner level sight words
95 yellow game cards – intermediate level sight words
95 red game cards – advanced level sight words

name.value: Rollin' Bones: Pirates of the Caribbean (On Stranger Tides) Dice Game

item.description:
Description from the package back:
Push your luck as you bury, capture and steal bones in this exciting Pirates dice game. Actual bone shaped dice. Roll the bone dice to Capture, Bury, Steal or Lose Em All. Bury the most bones, score the most points and you win. Take and play anywhere with the mesh storage bag for your bones.

Play Description:
Beginning the game each player takes one bone from the bone yard (pile), youngest player rolls first. Each bone (die) is marked with 4 symbols (Skull and crossbones, a sword, a bone, and a shovel. 
Roll a bone draw another bone from the bone yard (roll all the bones again unless no bones were available)
Roll a sword and steal a bone from another player (roll all the bones again, unless no bones were taken)
Roll a shovel and you can bury one bone
But watch out, if ye rolls a skull ye loses all yer bones (except buried ones)

When all bones have been buried each player rolls all they have... The most skulls rolled is the winner.

A game should not last more than 15mins.

Game Contents:
14 Plastic Bone Dice
1 Brown Mesh Carry Bag
1 Rules Set

item.description:
Welcome to world of Storm the Castle!, a 1-4 player semi-cooperative game in which you take the exciting role of one of the four marauding Dark Forces armies in a race to breach Castle StormHaven's walls, overrun the defenders, and claim victory by reaching the castle's keep first.

Breaching Castle StormHaven's thick walls is no easy feat. It takes a desire for loot, hordes of your minions willing to be led to certain death (err, victory), cunning strategy, and a touch of treachery. The first player whose Dark Force unit enters the keep, by the end of turn eight, is truly the mightiest champion and claims total victory for his army.

The Story So Far - The Invasion Begins!

Castle StormHaven is guarded vigilantly by brave defenders comprised of an alliance between Men, Elves, Halflings, and Dwarves. For over 300 years, these defenders have repelled numerous invasions from the Badlands, home to the subterranean Dark Elf marauders and the mysterious sect of arcane bending wizards, the Arcanists. StormHaven is the first and last line of defense from keeping the fertile farmlands and gold mines of Western Holmenstein from being overrun.

Years ago, a mysterious masked and exceptionally short villain appeared with the goal of uniting the Badlands and ruling over Holmenstein. Dubbed "the Boss" by his cohorts, he promised gold and power to those who would follow him. First the Dark Elves, then the Arcanists joined his Dark Forces. Soon after, the Orc pirate raiders joined the growing army and brought with them their crazed goblin allies and monstrous cousins, the giants. Knowing The Boss' army needed further strength to overwhelm Castle StormHaven's defenses, he revealed the last piece of strategy for domination, the Undead Horde of the BlackSoot Swamps.

Now the four dark force armies – Dark Elves, Arcanists, Orc and Goblins of the Green Tide, and the innumerable Undead host – begin their long march east.

Dark Force Army Overview

Choosing your army is part of the fun of Storm the Castle! Each Dark Force army has unique units, power cards, combos and strategies. Is one better than the other - no! It’s how you use your strengths while minimizing your weakness. Each army has a fair opportunity to win.

The Green Tide: Orcs, goblins, giants, and other humanoids make up this loose tribal alliance. Specializing in brute force and strange Eastern technology, players who enjoy large explosions, brute strength, and dangerous yet untested weapons will enjoy smashing their way to victory with this army.

Pros: Hard hitting units with lots of equipment upgrades. Power cards primarily focused on attacking and smashing. The rock lobber is one of the most effective siege weapons in the game. Goblin sappas provide for cheap, hard hitting units.
Cons: Moderately expensive units. Lack of diversity in their power cards utility. Equipment can be deadly for both you and foe!

The Arcanists: Mixing metal with magic produces stunning results. These masters of the forbidden arcane arts use their talents to manipulate the minds and outcomes of events of their allies and enemies. Players who enjoy using tactics that harness deadly magics and powers to manipulate events will surely enjoy the awesome power of the Arcanists.

Pros: Incredible power cards that can shift game elements to your favor. Several long range spells and abilities to generate quick magic. 
Cons: Many of your units have low health and are easily destroyed.

The Undead Horde: The walking dead from the Blacksoot Swamps know of one thing - how to feed! Their power derives from their ever increasing numbers and ability to sustain damage while pressing forward. Players looking to overwhelm the Fantasy Defenders with hordes of undead while using dark magic will find great pleasure in fielding this army.

Pros: Your units cause fear and can take quite a bit of damage. Inexpensive units allow you to swarm and overrun the Fantasy Defender’s defenses. 
Cons: Though your units are many, they don’t hit hard. Magic can be hard to build up as its dependent upon how many undead units you have in play.

The Dark Elves: From the deep recesses of forgotten lands nestled deep within the earth come the masters of marauding, the Dark Elves. Known for their exceptional arts in battlefield tactics and archery, no foe is safe from the tips of their arrows to the teeth of their treachery. Players who revel in treachery, backstabbing and shooting should choose the Dark Elves.

Pros: Awesome ranged attacks and power cards to support them. Treacherous power cards give you a unique competitive edge against other players.
Cons: Squishy units means you’ve got to know when to fight and when to move in. Players may give you strange “can I trust you” looks. Lack of strong melee units.

item.description:
Pokemon Pom Jong the new game with a 5000 year old tradition.

Pom Jong is a game derived from its similarities to Gin Rummy and Mah Jongg.

Pom Jong characters are easier to learn than Mah Jongg characters, and the rules of the game are simpler.

As with Mah Jongg, the game of Pom Jong has its roots in China and is comprised of 81 plastic tiles of different suits and symbols showing your favorite Pokemon characters!

The tiles are collected and discarded by players one by one as they try to build sets, much like Gin Rummy, until one of the players acquires a winning hand.

Players may join or leave at the beginning or end of any hand.

Pom Jong is a fast and exciting game than can be played between 4 players and appeals to all ages.

It can be a family game, a teen game, an adult game, or solitary pastime.

This is a family game to be played by old & young alike!

item.description:
Set in a remote research station, Raptor Rampage is a fun dinosaurs (velociraptors) versus humans game of survival for 2-6 players.

Players take sides, being either Raptors or Heroes. Along the way Heroes must search for weapons and items to defend themselves from the vicious Raptors. Meanwhile the Raptors use their instincts and guile to eradicate those pesky humans and their dangerous weapons.

To add to the variety, each character has their own set of skills and abilities. Add in a liberal dose of dice rolling, various missions and a modular map, Raptor Rampage is loads of rompin' chompin' good fun.

Scalaparola is a collection of 10 games to play with words, for 2-6 players.
The box includes tiles and cards featuring letters of the alphabet.
The characteristic of this collection is that the words formed during play earn more value if they match a category choose at random before starting.
The games are:

CROSSWORDS
Is to form words on the board with the tiles, making them cross each other.

ANAGRAMS
The goal is to earn more points by transforming or composing the words on the board.

SCALAPAROLA
Words are made using the cards you receive at the beginning of the game. Player who gets rid of all their cards win.

MIXER
Extracted 18 cards, players must form words and intersections using all 18 letters.

LONGEST WORD
Players must form the longest word using the 18 cards drawn at the beginning of the game.

THE HIDDEN WORDS
From a grid of cards, players turn as many cards as the value of the roll of a dice. If they can form a word with these letters withdraw the cards, otherwise they turn and make them available to other players. The memory component in this game rewards players.

TOUR OF WORDS
Players are given a card and select a category. Who can form a word that starts with the received card receives points. Whoever reaches the target score early in the game wins.

WORDS OF INTRIGUE
Players must make up the largest number of words with 18 letters selected at the beginning of the game. Player who arrives first at the target score.

PASSWORD
A player secretly made up a word of at least 5 letters. So put 30 cards on the table and represent how many letters the word is formed that has made. The other players must turn round a card, the first player declare whether it is part of his word, the player who first manages to figure out what was the word formed early in the game win.

WORD FOR WORD IN
Select a category, players are dealt 7 cards. They must form a word, as long as possible, inherent to the category selected, and the letters received. Player who first reaches 50 points.

In this game each player must first form a team, moving on the path outside of the board, meeting events, financing, buying players.
 When his team will be ready to enter the central area of the board, will play the matches.
 Games against neutral teams (not represented by any player) the points value of the team will determine the winner, while against teams of the other participating in the game, you will shoot to door with the special ball, to determine the outcome of the challenge.
 The victory means the gain of a card-challenge, the player who at the end of the game earned the highest number of cards-challenge win the game.

This game simulates a football match.
 Each player builds his own team by buying pieces until you reach the number of points determined at the beginning of the game.
 Each piece has a different buying value. Pieces are marked on the values â€‹â€‹of defense, attack, movement and power of the player that they represent.
 It possible deploy its own team in the field with the classic patterns of football: 3-5-2, 4-4-2, 4-3-3 (defenders-midfielders-forwards).
 A match lasts two periods of 16 rounds for a total of 32 rounds.
 There is also a deck of cards to use in contrast, to determine if any foul actions.
 Components of the game:
 1 board;
 68 pieces players divided into two teams;
 72 card comparison;
 2 pieces ball;
 1 die;
 regulation

The naval Battle of the Downs took place on 31 October 1639 (New style), during the Eighty Years' War and was a decisive defeat of the Spanish, commanded by Admiral Antonio de Oquendo, by the United Provinces, commanded by Lieutenant-Admiral Maarten Tromp.

The game includes an A4 map, 102 counters and markers and 4 pages of rules.

One player is in charge of the Dutch fleet the other one is in charge of the Spanish fleet.

The game turn includes:
A/ Wind direction
B/ Player one game turn (Command, movements, combats)
C/ Player two game turn (Command, movements, combats)
D/ Victory check

The game has 3 scenarios:
1/ September 27 1639
2/ September 28 1639
3/ The Battle of the Downs, October 31st 1639

item.description:
The players are divided into two teams and have to compete in 18 categories. The players try to fulfill tasks requested by cards. Most of these categories require the players to explain or tell something with a handicap, such as letting your tongue hang out while you pronounce a difficult word and such, forming a sentence which contains the same word twice in a row, etc.
For each fulfilled task, the team moves up ten percent on a kind of "fun indicator" (Stimmungsbarometer in German). At certain intervals, a "fitness test" is required before the team's pawn can move on to the next sector on the game board or eventually cross the finish line to win the game.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

An interesting game, that looks like it is card dominoes but it is a game in its own right. Each player chooses a colour and places that card in front of them. It has no part in the game other than to remind players who has which colour. I don't know why but the rules say that "this colour is kept for the WHOLE EVENING". (Their capital letters, not mine).
The deck is shuffled and each player gets 10 cards. The remaining undealt cards form a face-down draw pile. A player may, in turn, play one card in the middle of the board as in dominoes. Then the player replenishes his hand by drawing a card from the pool. The winner is the player who has the colour of the last card played when the pool is exhausted. The rules give a strategy tip - do not play cards of your own colour until victory looms. This will give you a good chance to play for a win.
Betting is suggested as an option, even onlookers are encouraged to bet on who will win.

name.value: Deuce, The Card and Lawn-Tennis Card-Dice Game

item.description:
Card game for 2 or 4 players
All the cards are dealt to each player and placed in front of them face-down. The server now rolls the die and that indicates if the serve was good or a fault. If the ball stays in play, the opponent reveals his first card from the stack in front of him. If the return of serve is good then the original server reveals the top card from his stack, and so on until the point is won.
Scoring is exactly the same as in real tennis.

A tongue-in-cheek game by Greg Costikyan, self published when he was a playtester at SPI.

The map was inspired by what looks like a fire alarm/evac map like you may see posted in your workplace.

The idea is the SPI trolls (playtesters) are in revolt against their SPI masters, Howie Barasch, Jim Dunnigan, Terry Hardy et al.

The object is to run around knocking people out in an attempt to take over the building, the SPI guys can knock out playtesters and drag them to the elevator, having the security guard remove them from the building.

The weapons are dice, the soda whoosh guys have their soft drinks, a few other items to spice up the mix, a Sherman tank in the store room!

Victory is gauged on how quickly you clear the building, taking into consideration that the pizza delivery every night at 8 pm stuns the playtesters into a mass move to the break room!

The game also includes the lyrics to "We're an Armenian Band"

Heist is a competitive game with cooperative elements that has only one winner. You and other professional thieves have been hired to infiltrate a secret facility and loot the Executive Vault. As part of the agreement, you can keep anything else of value you discover along the way.

Thieves spend actions and each build a hand of skill-boosting Equipment cards used to overcome such obstacles as Bounty Hunters, Exploding Aerial Drones and Killer Robots. The game is highly social, and players will frequently work with (or double-cross) fellow thieves to advance through the building. But ultimately you’re in it for yourself ... despite what you may have told anyone else.

If any thief loots the Executive Vault and escapes the building, then the thief with the most total loot is the winner. But in an unusual twist, if you're caught as a thief, you're not out of the game. Instead, you "flip" and become an informant working for the authorities against the other thieves. If all the thieves are caught, then the informant with the most "credibility" gains immunity from crimes committed and wins.

The N Game pits players against each other in a race to the Nitrogen cycle finish line.

Players move their Nitrogen (N) tokens on the game board through the various “pools” (chemical forms) of the Nitrogen Cycle and back to the starting N2 pool. When one player has moved three of his/her N tokens through the cycle and back to N2, the game is over, and total scores determine the winner.

To move Nitrogen, players draw and play cards representing soil bacteria and the resources that these bacteria need. They also draw event cards. Event cards can affect the active player, another player, or the entire game.

This game was developed at The University of Wisconsin-Madison through funding from the Engage program to teach the Nitrogen cycle to university soil science students, as well as high school students.

name.value: Zombies en La Moneda: Juego de Cartas

item.description:
La Moneda is like the Chilean White House situated in Santiago.

"Zombies en La Moneda: Juego de Cartas" is a card game where players try to rescue as many people as they can in an apocalyptic Santiago, before human batteries that have control over the zombies get exhausted and zombies manage to get control over the city eating everybody’s brains.

This game is based in the successful chilean comic Zombies en La Moneda.

Each player begins with two cards in their hand. Cards can be humans, zombies, infected humans, cops or bombs. On each turn a player has to draw a card and then play a card.

Human cards (with values 1 to 5) are played in front of them and represent the people they have saved.

Zombies are played so that other player has to discard some of their human cards (which ones and how many depend on the zombie played).

Infected humans are very bad cards to have in your hand because they eat two human cards from the same player.

Cops can act as heroes and sacrifice themselves to save humans when attacked by zombies.

Finally bomb cards have 2 uses. They can be used to stop a zombie attack, or they can be used in any turn to gain an additional card to your hand. Either way a bomb would have exploded in "La Moneda".

When the sixth bomb explodes the game will end and the player with more humans saved will win the game!


Editorial Tabula Rasa presenta "Zombies en La Moneda: Juego de Cartas", producto basado en el exitoso cómic chileno homónimo de Mythica Ediciones.

ZeLM:JdC es un juego de cartas no coleccionables ágil, entretenido y rápido de aprender, para disfrutar de 2 a 6 jugadores. En este juego
deberás rescatar a la mayor cantidad de personas en un Santiago apocalíptico, antes de que se detonen las bombas que están dentro del
Palacio de La Moneda. Pero no todo será tan fácil, porque el rescate de cada persona podrá verse interrumpido por los zombies sedientos de
cerebros que vagan por la ciudad.

Objetivo Primario: Elimina la amenaza zombie. Destruye las 6 baterías humanas que dan energía y controlan a los zombies. La misión se dará por terminada una vez que las 6 baterías humanas, que se encuentran dentro del Palacio de La Moneda, sean detonadas.

Objetivo Secundario: Protege a la ciudadanía. Rescata a la mayor cantidad de personas posible y evita que sean víctimas de ataques zombies. Debes tener mucho cuidado porque hay personas que han sido infectadas y en cualquier momento pueden convertirse y atacar a tu propio grupo. Si te encuentras con la policía local, ésta te ayudará con la tarea de defender tu zona de rescate.


 Contenido/Contents: 66 cartas/cards - 1 manual/rulebook

item.description:
Fluxx gets the Science Fiction treatment. From the publisher: "Just when you thought that Fluxx had gone as far as it could go - it blasts off for the Stars! Explore the vastness of space-themed humor with your valiant Captain, Engineer, and, of course, your Expendable Crewman. Go check out that Small Moon – or is it really a Space Station? You may be swayed by Unseen Forces, held hostage by Evil Computers, or find your ship infested with Cute Fuzzy Aliens."

Like its brethren, Star Fluxx is the game of ever changing rules. It starts out as Draw 1, Play 1, but even that can change. When a Goal card is played, you can win by meeting the Goal, usually by having the correct Keeper cards in front of you. Action and Surprise cards help you to meet the Goal, or stop your opponent. Creeper cards usually prevent you from winning, but are sometimes necessary to meet the Goal.

item.description:
You are a modern day shaman and supernatural champion. Waging your secret war against dark forces intent on reshaping the universe, you also face off against destiny in the wake of an uncertain prophecy that foretells destruction but gives the promise of hope. Across the world, the infant Queens of Fate are being reincarnated into the world. Can you find them before the dark powers get to them?

--
These are the complete instructions on how to play a solitaire game called Queens of Fate, using only a deck of tarot cards and a large playing surface. I made up this game as a tool to help me learn to use and interpret the multi-faceted meaning of the tarot cards in different ways, and soon found both the game and its story to be quite addictive.

Gameplay consists of turning over cards from the deck, one at a time and resolving them. Depending on the type of card (classified in the game as Opposition, Arcana, Source, or Court), you will either play it into your play area, confront it in a challenge, or compare it to the previous card drawn. You have a set of Arcana cards and Source cards to use in battles, but each can only be used once.

The strategy of the game involves using (discarding) cards you have in play when an Opposition card comes up, or deciding whether not to confront at all and deal with the consequences. Playing cards in certain combinations allows you to "resurrect" cards from the discard pile.

The goal is to play the four Queens, and place one in each suite-themed play area. If you run out of cards before this happens, you lose the game. The Queens can be lost through losing battles to Obstacle cards, which may attack your Court cards or random cards from your deck.

name.value: Race to Adventure: The Spirit of the Century Exploration Game

item.description:
The Spirit of the Century setting blasts its way into the world of board games, riding a jetpack and armed with a lightning gun, in Race to Adventure: The Spirit of the Century Exploration Game!

Race to Adventure! is a fun, family-friendly board game for ages 8 and up that can be played in about half an hour. Fans of pulp will love the brightly-colored world of talking apes and flying jet-men, and busy families can have an evening of fun that doesn't take over the whole night.

For experienced gamers who love the "role selection" dynamic in board and card games, Race to Adventure! offers a strong introduction to those concepts that your friends will find less intimidating than similar Euro-games, yet still packed with enough complexity and configurability to challenge everyone.

Race to Adventure! is easy to learn and quick to play. Check out our ten-minute tutorial video in the videos section here.

Players grab their passports, place their pawns in a starting position at the Century Club, and then the race is on! Players take turns selecting exciting items to help them on their quest, like the Jet Pack, Zeppelin, or Lightning Gun. Each item determines what missions and actions the players can take on their turn. Once the items are chosen, everyone moves and takes action at exotic locations around the board, collecting stamps and clues as they go. The first player to rescue the prisoner from Atlantis, survive the Mummy's Curse, collect all nine passport stamps, and return to the Century Club wins the game!

item.description:
This is Game #21 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

The game is loosely related to Reversi and Othello. In this game players enter pieces onto the board, and sliding other pieces down. Players remove a line of enemy pieces that are part of a custodial capture between two of a player's piece, one being slid and another one.

The game differs from Reversi and Othello in that players place all their pieces on the board, and instead of converting over when part of a custodial trap, the enemy pieces are removed from the board.

This is Game #22 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard series.

This game borrows the concept of sowing pieces from the Mancala family of games. In it, pieces are sown in two dimensions, rather than a line. In addition, there is a limit to how many pieces are permitted on a space, restricting where players can sow their pieces to. Control of a space is governed by the last piece to be sown into it.

The is Game #23 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

This game is a diceless race game, where players move their pieces along a long and winding path to get their pieces to the End space, where they come off the board. Along the way, players are able to take shortcuts that accelerate their movement to the end, and also trap opposing pieces so they are not able to move.

This is Game #24 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

This game is a fusion of Turkish Checkers with the Tafl family of games. The game combines the jump capture and promotion found in games in the Checkers family, with the win conditions found in games in the Tafl family, with modifications made to both families of abstract strategy games, to work on an 8x4 board.

From the Turkish Checkers family comes orthogonal sliding and jumping, and promotion of pieces for the Defending side. The King side of the game borrows the goal of exiting off a side of the board from the Tafl famil.

This is Game #25 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

This game is a fusion of Lines of Action, Focus and Extinction Chess. In it, in order to keep pieces moving, a player must control at least one stack each containing 1 piece, 2 pieces, and 3 pieces. In order to move a stack on top of another stack, a player must have all their pieces on the board. If a player is unable to perform a legal move at the start of their turn, that player loses the game.

Paul Beykirch also was part of the design process and is listed as a co-designer of the game.

This is Game #26 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

This is a solitaire puzzle game, with variant rules to enable it to be played as a party puzzle game. In it, players attempt to reduce 6 dice that are rolled to a single die on the board, with value of 6 on top. As players move dice, they reduce in value. As players merge dice, the new dice on the space merged equals the sum of the two dice merging. Players are not permitted to combine dice to a value greater than six, and each die is permitted to only move in a line, one or more spaces.

Quick rules:

 Roll the six dice, and then place them on the board so they get reduced to a single die with a six on it.
 As a die moves into another die, the value of the die moved into is increased by the current value of the die moving, and the die moving is removed from the board.
 A single move for a die consists of moving in a straight line vertically, horizontally or diagonally, like a queen in chess. For each empty space a die moves into, it decreases its value by 1. A die may not be reduced to less than one doing this.
 Each die can perform, at most, one move per puzzle.

"PUNCH BUGGY NO PUNCH BACKS". Ah remember the good old days in the back seat with your siblings, and how red your arm was be the time you got to grandma's house? Now you can relive those fond memories without the pain, in the dice game "Backseat Battles".

Backseat Battles is played with 8 battle dice and 2 revenge dice. During the players turn they roll all 8 battle dice and set aside any hits they have rolled. The player continues to roll and building their score as long as they risk or until they roll no hits and dad pulls the car over losing all their hits. Beware of sibling rivalry, if a revenge is rolled, their opponent gets the chance to fight back and possibly steal their points.
 A simple game of lucky with a touch of strategy built in. For ages 6 and up.

Perplexus Epic is a solo dexterity 3-D maze game where players must maneuver a small marble around challenging barriers inside a transparent sphere, but where a wrong move can spell failure and require you to return to the start or a checkpoint. It is much more challenging than the original Perplexus with 125 barriers.

name.value: Defeat Into Victory: The Final Campaigns in Burma

item.description:
Publisher's blurb:

"The opportunities following the swift Japanese subjugation of Burma in early January 1942 were not exploited. For their chastened opponents, Allied operations in this theater of the war were limited to raids and small-scale offensives as war efforts in North Africa and Europe, as well as the South Pacific, drew higher priorities for resources and personnel. For much of 1943 and early 1944 the fighting in Burma was relegated to WWII's backwater by both sides. With the end of the monsoon season in 1944 the strategic situation had changed. Not only were Japanese fortunes declining precipitously elsewhere, but the build-up in Allied forces along the Burma/India border did not go unnoticed. Determined to pre-empt any Allied attack, the Japanese launched an offensive of their own in May, the largest they ever launched outside of China, against the Allied positions in and around Imphal and Kohima. The battles that raged among the jungles and mountainous hillsides of the Indian and Burma frontier, and the subsequent Allied victory that followed in July, marked a fundamental and permanent shift in the war. The Allied offensive in March 1945 was one marked by extensive planning and preparation, as well bold and daring maneuvers that not only took the Commonwealth and Indian forces across the Irrawaddy River to Rangoon, but crushed the defending Imperial Japanese Burma Area Army.

Defeat into Victory, by designer Paul Rohrbaugh, covers this neglected aspect of WWII history using a very interactive and easy to play design. The game has one 22" by 34" hex map that stretches from Dimapur in the north to Rangoon in the south. A countersheet with 280 half-inch units (mostly brigade and regiments in size) and approximately 16 pages of rules and charts round out the package. The game uses a chit-pull activation system. Rules cover supply (a crucial aspect in terrain that was among the most inhospitable of the war), various types of combat (fire, maneuver and assault), as well as morale and leadership. Rules also include random events (that simulate the effects of battles and decisions by higher-ups elsewhere), weather, Japanese suicide tank attacks (human combat destruction squads) and changing war goals. The air campaign is also simulated (in much more detail than generic "air points"). Scenarios include the initial Japanese offensive against Imphal and Kohima, two on the Allied 1945 offensive, as well as the Campaign Game. Tough decisions will have to be made by both sides as they allocate precious resources among their formations, determine their enemy's intentions and balance their plans, as well as attack and defend. "

name.value: NOIR: Deductive Mystery Game – Black Box Edition

item.description:
NOIR: Killer vs. Inspector is a two-player game of hidden identities and deduction. Each player receives a secret identity from among 25 suspects and an open role that determines his available moves and victory conditions.

The Killer plays by eliminating players, focusing more on intuition and reading his opponent. The Inspector uses secret information and his ability to accuse suspects to create a play style more focused around logical elimination of possibilities.

The game plays in 5 to 15 minutes, and is contained in a 54-card deck box for easy travel play.

NOIR: Deductive Mystery Game – Black Box Edition includes fifty suspect and fifty innocent cards as well as six game modes — including Killer vs. Inspector, Hitman vs. Sleuth, Spy Tag, Master Thief vs. Chief of Police — to test your mettle!

This is a religious game based on the Rosary. Players move along the "bead" pathway and answer questions. A correct answer moves a player's token forward... after he or she has recited the appropriate prayer. The first contestant to complete the rosary is declared the winner.

Rising Sun Railroads is one of the two games and seven expansions from Winsome Games to be released at Spiel 2011.

The sharpest railroad executives vie for the maximum return on their investment in this business game; the game objective is to connect cities with the railroad.

Colorado Midland is one of the two games and seven expansions from Winsome Games to be released at Spiel 2011.
